paragraph.content: section 49(3) is complied with in relation to the investigation on a date (the commencement date) not later than the expiration of the period of 5 years beginning when the enforcement notice became final,

subsection.continued: the Commission may within the relevant period serve notices under section 50(1) for the purposes of the investigation without needing to obtain the consent of the Chief Secretary for Administration. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

def.name: RelevantPeriod
def.leadIn: In subsection (1), relevant period (有關期間) means the period beginning on the commencement date and ending on the later of the following dates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the period of 5 years referred to in subsection (1)(b) expires;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date 2 years after the commencement date.

subsection.content: The Commission shall establish and maintain a register (the register) of enforcement notices which have become final.

subsection.leadIn: Any person shall be entitled, on payment of such reasonable fee, if any, as may be determined by the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect the register during ordinary office hours and take copies of any entry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to obtain from the Commission a copy, certified by the Commission to be correct, of any entry in the register.

subsection.content: The Commission may, if it thinks fit, determine that the right conferred by subsection (2)(a) shall be exercisable in relation to a copy of the register instead of, or in addition to, the original.
The Commission shall give general notice of the place or places where, and the times when, the register or a copy may be inspected.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Persistent discrimination
section.leadIn: If, during the period of 5 years beginning on the date on which either of the following became final in the case of any person, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an enforcement notice served on him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a finding by the District Court under section 54 that he has done an unlawful discriminatory act,

section.continued: it appears to the Commission that unless restrained he is likely to do an act falling within paragraph (b), or contravening section 30, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining him from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Proceedings in respect of a contravention of section 31, 32 or 33 shall be brought only by the Commission in accordance with the provisions of this section.

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for a decision whether the alleged contravention occurred; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application under subsection (4),

subsection.content: An application under subsection (2)(a) shall be made to the District Court.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a person has done an act which by virtue of section 31, 32 or 33 was unlawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that unless restrained he is likely to do further acts which by virtue of that section was unlawful,

subsection.continued: the Commission may apply to the District Court for an injunction restraining him from doing so; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may grant the injunction in the terms applied for or in more limited terms.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (4), if it appears to the Commission that a person has done an act which was unlawful by virtue of section 31, the Commission may apply to the District Court for an order imposing a financial penalty on such person; and the District Court, if satisfied that the application is well-founded, may make such an order.

The financial penalty imposed under subsection (5) shall not exceed $10,000 for the first occasion on which a penalty is imposed, and $30,000 for the second and any subsequent occasion on which a penalty is imposed in respect of the same person.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Help for aggrieved persons in obtaining information, etc.

subsection.leadIn: With a view to helping a person (the person aggrieved) who considers he may have been discriminated against in contravention of this Ordinance to decide whether to institute proceedings and, if he does so, to formulate and present his case in the most effective manner, the Commission may prescribe—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: forms by which the respondent may if he so wishes reply to any questions.

subsection.leadIn: Where the person aggrieved questions the respondent (whether or not in accordance with the forms referred to in subsection (1))—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: if it appears to the District Court that the respondent deliberately, and without reasonable excuse, omitted to reply within a reasonable period or that his reply is evasive or equivocal, the court may draw any inference from that fact it considers just and equitable to draw, including an inference that he committed an unlawful act.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the period within which questions must be served in order to be admissible under subsection (2)(a);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which a question, and any reply by the respondent, may be served.

subsection.content: Rules under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) may enable the District Court entertaining a claim under section 54 to determine, before the date fixed for the hearing of the claim, whether a question or reply is admissible under this section or not.

This section is without prejudice to any other enactment or rule of law regulating interlocutory and preliminary matters in proceedings before the District Court, and has effect subject to any enactment or rule of law regulating the admissibility of evidence in such proceedings.

subsection.def: In this section, respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

subsection.content: A person may lodge with the Commission a complaint in writing alleging that another person has done an act which is unlawful by virtue of a provision of this Ordinance.
A representative complaint may be lodged under subsection (1) in accordance with rules made under section 66.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), where a complaint is lodged under subsection (1), the Commission shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conduct an investigation into the act the subject of the complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matter which the act relates.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may decide not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is satisfied that the act is not unlawful by reason of a provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the person aggrieved by the act does not desire (or, in a case to which subsection (2) applies, none of the persons aggrieved by the act desires) that the investigation be conducted or continued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a period of more than 12 months has elapsed beginning when the act was done;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a case to which subsection (2) applies, it determines, in accordance with rules made under section 66, that the complaint should not be a representative complaint; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: it is of the opinion that the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission decides not to conduct, or to discontinue, an investigation into an act the subject of a complaint lodged under subsection (1), it shall by notice served on the person who lodged the complaint advise him of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for that decision.

subsection.content: Evidence of anything said or done by any person in the course of conciliation under this section (including anything said or done at any conference held for the purposes of such conciliation) is not admissible in evidence in any proceedings under this Ordinance except with the consent of that person.

subsection.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that subsection (6) shall not apply where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint is lodged under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a settlement has been effected of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Assistance other than by way of conciliation

subsection.content: Where a complaint has been lodged under section 62(1) but, for whatever reason, there has not been a settlement of the matter to which the act the subject of the complaint relates, then any person who may institute proceedings under this Ordinance in respect of that act may make an application to the Commission for assistance in respect of those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall consider an application under subsection (1) and may grant it if it thinks fit to do so, in particular where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the case raises a question of principle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is unreasonable, having regard to the complexity of the case or the applicant’s position in relation to the respondent or another person involved or any other matter, to expect the applicant to deal with the case unaided.

subsection.leadIn: Assistance by the Commission under this section may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving advice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arranging for the giving of advice or assistance by a solicitor or counsel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arranging for representation by any person including all such assistance as is usually given by a solicitor or counsel in the steps preliminary or incidental to any proceedings, or in arriving at or giving effect to a compromise to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other form of assistance which the Commission may consider appropriate,

subsection.continued: but paragraph (c) shall not affect the law and practice regulating the descriptions of persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address a court in, any proceedings except to the extent permitted under rules made (for the purposes of this Ordinance) in accordance with section 73D of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: In so far as expenses are incurred by the Commission in providing the applicant with assistance under this section the recovery of those expenses (as taxed or assessed in such manner as may be prescribed by relevant rules) shall constitute a first charge for the benefit of the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on any other costs or expenses which (whether by virtue of a judgment or order of the District Court or an agreement or otherwise) are payable to the applicant by any other person in respect of the matter in connection with which the assistance is given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so far as relates to any costs or expenses, on his rights under any compromise or settlement arrived at in connection with that matter to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings.

subsection.content: The charge conferred by subsection (4) shall be subject to any charge under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) and to any provision in that Ordinance for payment of any sum into the Supplementary Legal Aid Fund established under that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant rules (有關規則) means any rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

part.crossHeading: Period within which Proceedings are to be Brought

section.name: s64
section.heading: Period within which proceedings are to be brought

subsection.leadIn: The District Court shall not consider a claim under section 54 unless proceedings in respect of the claim are instituted before the end of the period of 24 months beginning—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the act complained of was done; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is a relevant report in relation to that act, with the day on which the report is published or made available for inspection under section 51,

subsection.leadIn: The District Court shall not consider an application under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 60(2)(a) unless it is made before the end of the period of 24 months beginning when the act to which it relates was done;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 60(4) unless it is made before the end of the period of 5 years so beginning.

subsection.content: For the purposes of determining the period under subsection (1) within which proceedings may be brought, where an act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 62(1), then the period that elapsed between the date when the complaint was lodged and the date when the complaint was disposed of under section 62(3) or (4), as certified in writing by the Commission, shall be disregarded. (Amended 29 of 2008 s. 106)

Notwithstanding subsections (1) and (2), the District Court may consider any claim or application which is out of time if, in all the circumstances of the case, it considers that it is just and equitable to do so.

For the purposes of subsection (4), the circumstances of the case include, in relation to any claim, whether the act to which the claim relates was the subject of a complaint lodged under section 62(1) and, if so, the period that elapsed between when the act was done and when the complaint was so lodged.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any act extending over a period shall be treated as done at the end of that period; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a deliberate omission shall be treated as done when the person concerned decided upon it,

subsection.continued: and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, a person shall be taken for the purposes of this section to decide upon an omission when he does an act inconsistent with doing the omitted act or, if he has done no such inconsistent act, when the period expires within which he might reasonably have been expected to do the omitted act if it was to be done.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend subsection (1) by substituting a longer period for the period specified in that subsection. (Amended 66 of 1999 s. 3)

def.name: RelevantReport
def.leadIn: In this section, relevant report (有關報告), in relation to an act referred to in that subsection (1), means a report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: published or made available for inspection under section 51; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from which it can reasonably be construed (and whether or not the report mentions, or was in any way prepared in consequence of, the act) that the Commission is of the opinion that the act, or the class of acts to which the act belongs, is unlawful under a provision of Part III, IV or V.

subsection.content: Section 87 of the relevant Ordinance applies in relation to the validity and revision of contracts, for the purposes of this Ordinance, subject to the modifications described in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The modifications referred to in subsection (1) are as follows—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the relevant Ordinance shall be construed as references to this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to any subsection of that section shall be construed as references to the corresponding subsection of this section incorporated by reference under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reference in that section to section 76 of that Ordinance shall be construed as a reference to section 54.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the Commission shall have the same power to make rules as it has under the relevant Ordinance and accordingly section 88 of that Ordinance applies to this Ordinance subject to the modifications described in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The modifications referred to in subsection (1) are as follows—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to section 84, 84(1) and 84(4)(d) of that Ordinance shall be construed as references respectively to section 62, 62(1) and 62(4)(d);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to rules shall be construed as a reference to rules made under this section;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to that section, a subsection or paragraph of that section shall be construed as a reference respectively to this section, the corresponding subsection or paragraph of this section incorporated by reference under subsection (1);

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to section 35 of that Ordinance shall be construed as a reference to section 25; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to that Ordinance shall be construed as a reference to this Ordinance.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Regulations to empower Commission to bring certain proceedings

subsection.content: The Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs shall have the same powers to make regulations for the purposes of this Ordinance as he has under the relevant Ordinance and accordingly section 89 of that Ordinance shall apply subject to the modification that the references to section 76(1) and 76(3) of that Ordinance shall be construed as references respectively to section 54(1) and 54(3). (Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)
Any regulations made under this section shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Amendment of Schedules
section.text: The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1 or 2 but any notice to amend Schedule 2 shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

td.p: Any discrimination against a person who has family status arising from a provision—
any contract of service or apprenticeship; or
